sub_title: MPA Graduate Seeking Entry-Level Position or Freelance Assignments
summary:
Hello! My name is John-Morgan, and I am open to full-time employment opportunities or freelance assignments. I come from the United States, but I have lived over four years in the Netherlands.

I have shown that I can adapt quickly to new challenges and thrive when pushed out of my comfort zone. I’m originally from a small town in Tennessee, but I completed my bachelor’s degree in Chicago. Following a one-year exchange program in Amsterdam, I returned to the Netherlands to attain my master’s. By forming connections with international peers, I improved my understanding of diverse perspectives and gained better methods for communicating. This allowed me to further implement the skills I developed during university and work experiences. I lived in The Hague for two years during my master’s studies, but I now reside in Utrecht. I am self-employed with an academic tutoring business online, but I also complete varied freelance projects.

I will show that I can excel when presented with an opportunity. Being quality-driven with an attention to detail, I aim to continually improve and cultivate new competencies. I am eager to apply my knowledge in an area of expertise, but I remain open to new ideas and ways of implementation. My academic and entrepreneurial background has developed the necessary qualities to surpass performance standards. In addition, I have volunteered and held leadership positions in various extracurricular organizations that improved my aptitude for interpersonal skills, team management, and collective problem-solving. My current ambition is to establish myself in the Dutch professional world and develop a greater network. I look forward to connecting with you, thanks!

projects.title: The Effects of Prison Education on Employment of the Formerly Incarcerated: A Meta-Analysis of Correctional Education Programs in the United States
projects.description:
Master's Thesis

Abstract:  A meta-analysis is conducted to estimate the intervention effect from educational program participation in prison. Value is added to existing research through inclusion of updated studies and utilization of estimation techniques to limit bias. Findings for post-release employment outcomes support a significant, positive effect from participation in correctional education. Program-type comparisons of academic and vocational programs provide less insight. Reliability of results is supported by robust inclusion criteria; test and correction for publication bias supports validity. Policy recommendations and suggestions for further research conclude.

contributors.headline: MPA Graduate Seeking Entry-Level Position or Freelance Assignments

projects.title: The Policy Paradox of Pain: An Analysis of U.S. Measures to Combat Chronic Pain and Opioid Addiction
projects.description: A collaborative research paper completed for the course Public Policy and Values. The aim was to research and analyze factors contributing to the United States government’s inability to enact and maintain effective policies addressing opioid abuse. This paper addressed the problems that led to and perpetuated the US opioid crisis; also their portrayal through the use of numbers, causes, and symbols. Policy goals are discussed as they impact solutions and barriers to reaching the intended effects.

contributors.headline: MPA Graduate Seeking Entry-Level Position or Freelance Assignments

projects.title: Social and Economic Development in Chicago's Chinatown District
projects.description: This was my second time participating in the IIT Interprofessional Projects Program. The group's objective was to partner with the Chinese American Museum of Chicago to develop a means to engage and educate the community at large, while encouraging Chinese cultural recognition. The creation of an interactive walking tour was implemented to promote social and economic relations between residents, members of surrounding communities, and visitors. We received two awards at the fall semester program showcase.

contributors.headline: MPA Graduate Seeking Entry-Level Position or Freelance Assignments

projects.title: Made in the USA:  Connecting Consumers with Domestically Sourced Products
projects.description: The IIT Interprofessional Projects Program groups together students from a variety of backgrounds and academic disciplines in an attempt to solve a high-level issue; this is designed to foster collaboration and innovation in an unconventional learning environment. During the summer of 2016, I joined a group with the goal of changing the consumption habits of American consumers to put a higher emphasis on American made products. Our team executed secondary research to recognize the factors influencing domestic production and consumption, then presented an argument against current trends. We also developed a tangible solution to benefit retail shoppers in the form of a location-based mobile application for finding nearby Made in USA products. I was very interested in the topic and proposed solution, so I decided to continue with this project in a second iteration. In Spring 2017, I worked with a new group of peers to complete primary research regarding our project, further refine our application interface, and develop new ways of reaching consumers. Our project received several awards at the annual program showcase.

contributors.headline: MPA Graduate Seeking Entry-Level Position or Freelance Assignments

projects.title: Consumption of Banking Services by University Students
projects.description: This project was completed as part of the curriculum for a Consumer Behavior course I participated in during Fall 2016. My partner and I performed extensive research to understand the interactions between our peers and financial institutions. We collected primary data through multiple methods including surveys and interview, then presented our findings and actionable insights upon completion of the course.
